dc:title: The dynamics of seed bank size and seed state of Medicago lupulina.
dc:creator: Pavone L.
dc:description: Seed bank density of black medick in an abandoned pasture in southern Ontario, Canada, was relatively small (600-2000 seeds m-2) compared with those reported for other pasture species (3700- 55 000 m-2), but roughly the same as the density reported for another legume, Trifolium dubium (2500 m-2). The seed bank was smallest following spring and summer germination and largest in late winter when most seeds had been detached from parent plants. The lowest seed density (600-1100 m-2) was recorded in grass-filled hollows. It was 2-3 times greater on ridges. In both ridge and hollow habitats the seeds, which have a hard seed coat, remained dormant throughout most of the year. The largest transition between dormancy states occurred during winter months when seed coats were scarified and innately dormant seeds entered a state of enforced dormancy. Some 78-85% of experimentally introduced seeds germinated within 12 months, mostly in spring (April-May). Normally only 30-40% of the natural seed bank would germinate in a single year. Medicago lupulina apparently has a persistent seed bank in the study area. The regenerative strategy of M. lupulina was compared with that of Hieracium floribundum which dominated ridge habitats in the study area. While both species had flourishing populations on ridges in the pasture, most seeds of H. floribundum survive for no more than 1 yr, and recruitment to the population is mainly vegetative. The strategy of M. lupulina appeared to be better suited to colonizing small patches of bare ground created by the activities of animals or by erosion.-from Authors

dc:title: Biological flora of the British Isles - Poa annua L.
dc:creator: Hutchinson C.S.
dc:description: Examines the geographical and altitudinal distribution of this perennial grass and discusses its habitat, communities, responses to biotic factors, morphology, floral biology and phenology. The article concludes with a reference to animal feeders or parasites and lists invertebrates which feed on the plant.-B.Walls

dc:title: Species richness of herbaceous fen vegetation in Broadland, Norfolk in relation to the quantity of above-ground plant material ( Cladium mariscus).
dc:creator: Wheeler B.D.
dc:description: Species density was negatively correlated with amount of above-ground plant material, particularly with total crop in September, but also with standing crop in September and with the amount of litter, especially that at the start of the season. Species density halved as September total crop increased by 1850 g m-2, September standing crop by 1200 g m-2 and April litter by 1630 g m-2. High values of total crop biomass were always associated with species poverty. These high values were produced by development of a large standing crop, or accumulation of litter, or both. A large standing crop may be accumulated by a productive vegetation or, to some extent, by plants of lower productivity with long-lived leaves (eg. Cladium mariscus, the litter of which is also persistent). Overall, there was an increase in species density with decrease in mass of crop and of litter but also an increase in variability so that both species-poor and species-rich vegetation with small total crop occurred. Vegetation very rich in species was found only when the above-ground September total crop was less than about 1500 g m-2. Management of sedge beds (summer mowing) is necessary for high species density. Managed reedbeds may have a slightly lower species density than unmanaged ones. -from Authors

dc:title: The ecology of a montane grassland in Sri Lanka. I. Quantitative description of the vegetation.
dc:creator: Pemadasa M.
dc:description: Altitude, aspect, micro-climate soil and degree of human interference are the most important environmental factors responsible for the considerable vegetational diversity.-from Authors

dc:title: The effect of grazing by a chrysomelid beetle, Gastrophysa viridula, on growth and survival of Rumex crispus on a shingle bank ( Rumex obtusifolius).
dc:creator: Whittaker J.
dc:description: The virtual absence of R. crispus on the shingle bank is attributed to the combined effects of grazing by G. viridula and flooding. Neither factor would by itself eliminate R. crispus. The presence of the beetle in sufficient numbers depends on availability of R. obtusifolius as an alternative food. -from Author

dc:title: The influence of shading and soil type on the growth of Galeobdolon luteum.
dc:creator: Packham J.R.
dc:description: Populations of this taxon growing in different environments, with a very varied range of plant associates, show marked differences in such features as stolon production, leaf width, chlorophyll content, and the extent of flowering and fruiting. Investigations of clones collected in Shropshire show that many of these differences are environmentally induced, although some are genetic in origin. In studies of phenotypic plasticity, plants of clonal and of seedling origin were grown in the open and beneath shade-screens in cold frames which at midday received approx 70%, 27% and 6% of the light available to the open treatment. Results are discussed. The success of Galeobdolon in woodlands is in large measure associated with its winter-green and stoloniferous habit and especially its adaptability in leaf structure and area with respect to light conditions.-from Authors

dc:title: The costs of reproduction in a tropical palm, Astrocaryum mexicanum.
dc:creator: Pinero D.
dc:description: There was an increase in reproductive effort with age and an inverse correlation between various measures of reproductive cost and fecundity. The 3-60% variation in reproductive effort for different ages, years and plots seems to be mainly controlled by the probability of reproduction rather than the amount of reproductive structures produced. The physiological reproductive effort appears to be constant over a wide range of environments and ages.-from Authors

dc:title: Studies of mineral cycling in a montane rain forest in New Guinea. IV. Soil characteristics and the division of mineral elements between the vegetation and soil.
dc:creator: Edwards P.
dc:description: Very similar deep profiles were found on ridge-crests, on gentle slopes and in valleys, but shallower, more stony profiles were found on a few very steep slopes. Generally, the A horizon was a 50-70- cm deep, well-drained humic clay loam (organic C 8.5-21.6% dry weight, total N 0.8-1.7% dry weight). The B horizon was 30-50 cm deep, more clayey, but still rich in organic matter (about 9% C and 0.6-0.9% N at 100 cm depth). The C horizon was 1-5 deep, and varied greatly in detail. The humus was a well-defined crumb mull; 68-120 earthworms m-2 were found in the top 100 cm. Highly hydrated amorphous iron oxides dominated the inorganic fraction. The pH was 5.6-6.6 and the cation exchange capacity 61-78 m equiv. per 100 g. The exchangeable K, Ca and Mg were concentrated in the top 10 cm, where the base-saturation was about 20-80% (cf.4-5% at 60 cm). The concentration of total PO4-P was high, increasing from 1.5- 2.1 mg g-1 at the surface to 2.8-4.0 mg g-1 at 100 cm. The soils possessed several features that could, together, partially explain the exceptional stature (33-37 m) of the forest. The proportional distribution of mineral nutrient capital between living plants, dead plant material, and soil is discussed.-from Authors

dc:title: Studies on the population biology of the genus Viola. IV. Spatial pattern of ramets and seedlings in three stoloniferous species.
dc:creator: Schellner R.
dc:description: The spatial pattern of demographic variables of ramets and seedlings in 16 populations of Viola blanda, V. pallens and V. incognita were analysed using a variety of approaches (area and distance methods, G-tests of heterogeneity based on area counts, neighbourhood analysis, spatial autocorrelation). The variables considered were the position of ramets in space and time, emergence and mortality of ramets and seedlings. Emergence of new seedlings is clumped in space. The seedlings tend to be more numerous in areas where overall ramet density is low, indicating that seed germination or seedling emergence or both are inversely correlated with overall density of ramets. Seedling survival is affected by density. Ramets 1-yr-old or older appear to be aggregated or randomly distributed in space. The pattern of emergence of new ramets from stolons and the pattern of ramet death is random in space and not density dependent. It is proposed that seedling germination or survival or both are density dependent, but that the pattern of adult ramet distribution, vegetative production of new ramets and ramet mortality is more sensitive to environmental variables such as light, water and nutrients which are unevenly distributed on the forest floor.-from Authors

dc:title: Competition and coexistence in a North Carolina grassland. III. Mixtures of component species.
dc:creator: Fowler N.
dc:description: Species used were Anthoxanthum odoratum, Poa pratensis, Plantago lanceolata, Rumex acetosella, Salvia lyrata and Cerastium glomeratum. Density had little effect upon the outcome of competition between species. In 2-species mixtures containing Plantago and Poa, the species which formed a smaller proportion of the mixture had larger individuals, encouraging coexistence of these 2 species. Soil fertility and time of year affected intensity and outcome of competition. In 2 of 6 pairs of species, 1 species was dominant in one environment, but the other species became dominant in another environment. Spatial variation in soil conditions and seasonal variation in the environment may thus be responsible for the coexistence of some of the species. The results of each 2-species mixture may be summarized by identifying 1 species as the competitive dominant and the other as the competitive subordinate; when these summaries are combined a consistent, linear, order of all of the species results for each season and level of soil fertility. The order of the species differs between seasons and between fertility levels.-from Author

dc:title: Structural characteristics and adaptations of desmid communities.
dc:creator: Coesel P.
dc:description: In alkaline, open water habitats, as eutrophication increased, there was a decrease in desmid diversity, and an increase in the proportion of planktonic forms. Submerged fen-hollows were dominated, in relatively eutrophic sites, by small desmids with short generation times. In relatively oligotrophic sites, larger desmids with longer generation times prevailed. Greatest desmid diversity occurred in the middle part of the trophic range; this is explained by a greater niche differentiation resulting from frequent fluctuations in nutrient concentrations in the habitat. In emergent fen habitats, desmid diversity decreased with decreasing moisture content and rising acidity. The relative contribution of omniradiate forms with a small surface:volume ratio increased. -from Author

dc:title: Biological flora of the British Isles - Carex arenaria L.
dc:creator: Noble J.C.
dc:description: Examines the geographical and altitudinal distribution of the sedge Carex arenaria in Great Britain and Europe, and discusses its habitat, communities, response to biotic factors, gregariousness, morphology, phenology, floral biology and animal feeders or parasites, concluding with a summary of the species' recorded history.-B.Walls

dc:title: Response of Adenostoma fasciculatum and Ceanothus greggii chaparral to nutrient additions.
dc:creator: McMaster G.S.
dc:description: Urea (8 g N m-2), superphosphate (4 g P m-2) and urea plus superphosphate ((8 g N + 4 g P) m-2), were applied in early spring 1978 to 26 yr-old chaparral, with A. fasciculatum and C. greggii the predominant shrubs. Adenostoma responded to the three treatments by producing larger shoots in 1978. In 1979, without additional fertilizer, only the N treatment remained effective. For Ceanothus the largest response was to the P and N + P treatments in 1978. In 1979 shoots in all treatments were similar to or smaller than those in control. Addition of P significantly increased the number of inflorescences in Adenostoma, although this effect did not last into the 2nd year. Likewise, N, P, and N + P produced a significant increase in the number of new shoots m-2 of canopy. In Ceanothus a fertilizer effect was not found on either inflorescence growth or the number of new shoots. The above-ground biomass of annual species was significantly increased in 1978 and 1979 by N, and particularly by N + P. Phosphorus reduced the growth of annual species, especially grasses.-from Authors

dc:title: Self-thinning in Trifolium subterraneum populations transferred between full daylight and shade.
dc:creator: Westoby M.
dc:description: The self-thinning rule describes an outer boundary on the trajectories which even-aged stands of plants can follow in a space of log biomass v. log density. An important variant to the rule occurs in dense shade, but the exact nature of the variant remains unclear. Three alternative models of the effect of dense shade on the rule are described. Stands of Trifolium subterraneum were grown in a glasshouse in full daylight and others shaded at 30% of full daylight; after a period, some full-light stands were moved to the shade, and some shaded stands to full daylight. The slope of the trajectory of a stand growing in shade is determined not only by the light climate, but also by its position with respect to the relevant thinning line. This observation excludes one of the models.-from Authors

dc:title: Factors affecting the density response of Vulpia fasciculata.
dc:creator: Watkinson A.
dc:description: Growth in dry weight of individual plants in populations which were watered regularly and not thinned was markedly affected by both density and date of germination. By the final harvest, total yield was largely independent of the number of seeds sown and date of germination. There was a simple allometric relationship between number of seeds produced per plant and shoot dry weight. The same relationship did not apply to spikelet number; fine-tuning of the allometric response was through the number of seeds set per spikelet. The populations which were thinned by half at various stages of the life-cycle showed a similar weight-density response to that shown by the unthinned populations, except that for the corresponding density at maturity the plants were smaller. A discrete (difference) population dynamics model is used to show how the time at which individuals die can affect population size. Time of thinning may reduce population size by up to 57%. Drought during flowering reduced seed set, produced a more marked density- dependent reduction in fecundity, and masked differences between the thinning treatments in their response to density. -from Author

dc:title: Studies of mineral cycling in a montane rain forest in New Guinea. V. Rates of cycling in throughfall and litter fall.
dc:creator: Edwards P.
dc:description: Average throughfall on 4 sites was 68 + or - 3.4% of the rainfall (3960 mm in 1969; 4010 mm in 1970). Stemflow was less than 1% of throughfall. Estimated quantities (kg ha-1 yr-1) of minerals in the rainfall were 6.5 N, 0.53 P, 7.3 K, 3.6 Ca and 1.3 Mg, and mean quantities leached from the canopy were 29.6 N, 2.5 P, 71.1 K, 19.0 Ca and 10.9 Mg. Mean returns of minerals in the litter fall were 90.8 N, 5.1 P, 27.8 K, 94.7 Ca and 19.2 Mg. The return of minerals in throughfall and litter fall was remarkably similar on the 4 sites but certain minor between-site differences are discussed. Quantities of minerals in the standing crop of litter on the forest floor (mean 6.46 t ha-1) were (kg ha-1) 91 N, 4.8 P, 11.5 K, 96 Ca and 14.5 Mg. Some general conclusions are drawn concerning the differences in nutrient turnover in lowland and montane rain forests. Amounts of P, K, Ca and Mg returned annually in the throughfall and litter of montane forests overlap with the values found in lowland forest, but the return of N is lower. This presents particular problems of interpretation in view of the huge amounts of nitrogen present in the soil of the montane forest, and the substantial amounts in the annual throughfall. Nitrogen is thus probably fixed in the phyllosphere and becomes immobilized in the soil and so is unavailable to plants. -from Author Botany School, Univ. of Cambridge, UK.

dc:title: The ecology of a montane grassland in Sri Lanka. V. Interference in populations of four major grasses.
dc:creator: Pemadasa M.
dc:description: Increasing density considerably reduced vegetative size and reproductive potential of the 4 species. In mixtures, Pennisetum polystachyon suppressed, and Eulalia trispicata was suppressed by, every companion species; Themeda tremula depressed the growth of Cymbopogon nardus. The competitive ability of the more aggressive species was accentuated by clipping, that of the less aggressive species reduced. Time of establishment modified the competitive advantage of species; early-sown plants severely suppressed the late-sown plants regardless of the potential vigour, aggressiveness and competitive ability. The importance of human impact on the dynamics of these species in the grassland is discussed.-from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal changes in the concentrations of nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium, and in the density of mycorrhiza, in biennial and matrix-forming perennial species of closed chalkland turf.
dc:creator: Gay P.
dc:description: Species which occur on chalk-derived soils in Britain may be divided into those which are 'turf-compatible' (able to regenerate in closed turf) and those which are 'turf-incompatible' (able to develop only on sizeable patches of bare soil). Seasonal changes in the concentrations of N, P and K, and the density of mycorrhiza, were studied in spontaneous populations of 4 turf-compatible biennial species (Blackstonia perfoliata, Centaurium erythraea, Gentianella amarella, Linum catharticum) and 3 matrix-forming perennial species (Carex flacca, Festuca ovina, Sanguisorba minor) of chalk grassland. The concentrations of N, P and K in six turf-incompatible annual and biennial species were studied in the spring. Most of the N, P and K accumulated by the turf-compatible biennial plants was absorbed during their 2nd summer, at the time of their fastest growth. Concentrations of N, P and K in the turf-compatible biennial plants at maturity were similar to those in the perennial plants sampled at the same time. Concentrations of N, P and K in the shoots of the turf-compatible biennial plants in spring were much lower than those in the shoots of the turf-incompatible annuals and biennials sampled at the same season. The mycorrhiza of plants of the 4 turf-compatible biennial species are tentatively interpreted as variants of the vesicular- arbuscular type. The density of mycorrhiza showed marked seasonal variation, being highest in the autumn of the 1st year and the summer of the 2nd. Seedlings of species representing all 3 types of plant became mycorrhizal within c.2 wk of germination.-from Authors

dc:title: Responses of plants from three successional communities to a nutrient gradient.
dc:creator: Parrish J.
dc:description: All 18 species studied germinated over a wide range of nutrient concentrations. Early successional species began and completed germination sooner at all nutrient concentrations than did late successional species. There was an increase in total germination at moderate nutrient concentrations, but at the highest concentration, germination of most of the species was reduced. Plant survival at higher nutrient concentrations was significantly less than at low concentrations. Early successional species were less affected than were mid- and late successional species. Most species from the early and late successional assemblages grew fastest at the intermediate nutrient concentration, while mid-successional species grew fastest at the low nutrient concentration. Early successional species had higher concentrations of nutrients in their shoots and more marked changes in shoot nutrient concentration with increased concentration of nutrients in the soil than did species from mid- and late successional assemblages. Species from the late successional community had narrower response breadths (Levin's B) and smaller proportional similarity among then than did species of the earlier assemblages. Past competition resulting in niche divergence was most important in the organization of the late successional community, while competition within each season was important in the organization of the early successional community but only after other factors had determined the number and identity of the competitors.-from Authors

dc:title: Experimental studies on slug-plant interactions. IV. The performance of cyanogenic and acyanogenic morphs of Trifolium repens in the field.
dc:creator: Dirzo R.
dc:description: During the growing season (spring and summer), slightly more acyanogenic plants survived, and their rate of leaf and stolon production was slightly greater than that of cyanogenic plants. These differences were not apparent during the rest of the year. Only molluscs consistently preferred the acyanogenic plants. Weevils appeared not to be deterred by cyanogenesis and sheep appeared to change their preference from one morph to the other at different times of the year. There was damage by pathogens to the leaves of both morphs, but infection by the systemic rust Uromyces trifolii appeared almost exclusively on cyanogenic plants. During the winter, frost damage caused tissue necrosis and death of leaflets; frost damage was significantly greater on the cyanogenic leaves. Mollusc grazing is thus only one of the several forces affecting the cyanogenesis polymorphism in white clover. -from Authors

dc:title: On the conifer regeneration gap in New Zealand: the dynamics of Libocedrus bidwillii stands on South Island.
dc:creator: Veblen T.
dc:description: The structures of stands characterized by L. bidwillii, one of the main species for which regeneration failure has been postulated, were studied in 5 South Island localities representing a wide range of site conditions and species composition. Small-scale gap-phase regeneration of L. bidwillii occurs where poor drainage reduces the abundance and vigour of the young trees of most of the species in the gap. Where the vegetation has been massively disturbed by exogenous phenomena such as land slides or extensive windthrow, L. bidwillii often establishes in relative abundance in association with trees such as Phyllocladus alpinus and Nothofagus solandri. The regeneration failure hypothesis is a logical consequence of climax theory according to which old stands are expected to be in equilibrium. A dynamic scheme which does not require a stable end-point for succession and which emphasizes continuous change, even in old forests, is more consistent with the dynamics of L. bidwillii.-from Authors

dc:title: Seed production and seed mortality in a temperate forest shrub ( witch-hazel, Hamamelis virginiana).
dc:creator: De Steven D.
dc:description: Fates of H. virginiana fruits from initial fruit set to seed maturation and dispersal were determined in 1978, when fruit crops were low, and 1979, when fruit set was 5.6 times greater. Fruit was lost through physiological abortion (cessation of growth and eventual abscission); damage by caterpillars; infestation by a host-specific seed weevil (Pseudanthonomus hamamelidis, Curculionidae); and consumption by squirrels. Infestation by the weevil was higher in the low-fruiting year of 1978, but weevils were satiated by the abundant fruit production of 1979. Seed consumption by squirrels showed a compensatory trend, being greater in 1979 than in 1978. Although a similar percentage of fruits survived in both years, the substantially higher fruit set in 1979 resulted in much greater viable seed production than in 1978. Consumers increase the variability of seed recruitment into H. virginiana populations by severely reducing seed output in low fruiting years.-Author

dc:title: The ecology of a montane grassland in Sri Lanka. III. Germination of three major grasses.
dc:creator: Pemadasa M.
dc:description: The germination of Eulalia trispicata, Pennisetum polystachyon and Themeda tremula is influenced by light, temperature, soil moisture concentration, soil surface heterogeneity and the depth of burial; the light and temperature effects decreased as the seed aged. The timing of natural germination is determined by innate and enforced dormancy mechanisms and is synchronous with the monsoonal rains.-from Authors

dc:title: Studies of mineral cycling in a montane rain forest in New Guinea. III. The distribution of mineral elements in the above- ground material.
dc:creator: Grubb P.
dc:description: Concentrations of N, Ca and Mg generally increased toward the centre of the trunks of large trees, while that of P decreased; K and Na were variable. Concentrations of N, P and Mg in the wood tended to increase with height, but there were no significant trends in the bark. Intraspecific differences were considerable, and interspecific ones large. The mean concentrations of N, P, K and Mg generally increased along the series: trunk wood < branches < trunk bark < twigs < leaves. For Ca they increased along the series trunk wood < branches < leaves < twigs < trunk bark. The concentrations of N, P and K in leaves fell with increasing age, but that of Ca increased and those of Na and Mg were variable. Concentrations of N, P, K and Na were not consistently different in saplings and trees of the same species, but those of Ca and Mg were higher in sapling leaves. Concentrations of all 6 elements in small trees, saplings, seedlings and climbers varied greatly between species, but the mean values for leaves, or for stems of similar girth, were similar in all these life-forms. The vascular epiphytes differed in their consistently low foliar concentrations of N. For the whole forest, the above-ground capital was estimated to be (in kg ha-1) 850 N, 49 P, 700 K, 31 Na, 1500 Ca and 210 Mg.-from Authors

dc:title: Regulation of flower, fruit and seed production by a monocarpic perennial, Yucca whipplei.
dc:creator: Aker C.L.
dc:description: Number of flowers reaching anthesis was directly proportional to size of rosette. Number of fruits initiated on a plant was much less than, but proportional to, number of flowers produced. Many fruits were aborted and abscised prematurely. Mature fruit production was determined by both size of rosette (or inflorescence) and number of fruits initiated. Mature fruit set (mature fruits/flowers) averaged 9.1% in 1979 and 10.0% in 1980 in the central California population studied. Number of ovules per capsule did not vary with plant size, but average seed weight was positively correlated with rosette size at one site. Yucca whipplei regulates its maternal expenditure at the stage of flower determination and fruit maturation. Unpredictable pollinator availability both within and between seasons favours this pattern of reproduction. A major difference in rainfall between the 2 yr of study had no significant effect on percentage mature fruit set. The plants may respond to changes in moisture availability by adjusting size of inflorescence rather than proportion of flowers maturing to fruits.-from Author

dc:title: Experimental studies on slug-plant interactions. III. Differences in the acceptability of individual plants of Trifolium repens to slugs and snails.
dc:creator: Dirzo R.
dc:description: Cyanogenesis markedly reduced but did not wholly prevent damage to the clover leaves. In areas of high density of active molluscs (Agriolimax caruanae, Ag. reticulatus, Arion ater, Helix aspersa) the cyanogenic morphs were over-represented; in areas of low density of active molluscs, the acyanogenic morphs were over-represented. Slugs fed on monotonous diets of lettuce grew considerably faster than did those feeding on monotonous diets of either cyanogenic or acyanogenic clover leaves. Slugs fed on cyanogenic leaves made slightly smaller live-weight gains, or lost weight faster, than did those fed on acyanogenic leaves. Results are interpreted to suggest a possible co-evolutionary pathway of the mollusc-clover interaction. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of added nutrients on dune swards grazed by rabbits.
dc:creator: Boorman L.
dc:description: Different combinations of N, P and K were added to two nutrient-poor, rabbit (Oryctolagus cuniculus) grazed dune swards at Holkham, Norfolk. Because of intense rabbit grazing in the area, perennial grasses did not dominate the sward, and only very few unpalatable perennials were favoured by nutrient addition. Annual species generally declined in frequency when fertilizer was added, as did the cover of bryophytes and lichens, with a reduction in species diversity. This was most marked with treatments containing N. Reaction to P and K treatments differed according to species. The relatively diverse plant communities at Holkham apparently owe their existence both to low nutrient status and to relatively high rabbit grazing intensity. -from Authors

dc:title: Influence of soil heterogeneity on the coexistence of grassland species.
dc:creator: Fitter A.
dc:description: In 15 lowland grasslands, as the quotient of root density in the lower (5-10 cm) layer of soil to that in the upper (0-5 cm) layer increases so there is a decrease in number of species per unit area and in an index of dominance. Soil heterogeneity is shown experimentally to influence the coexistence of species.-from Author

dc:title: The ecology of flowers of chalk grassland and their insect pollinators.
dc:creator: Lack A.J.
dc:description: The flowering periods of important insect-pollinated herbs were determined. The most prominent species were Helianthemum nummularium, Hippocrepis comosa and Onobrychis viciifolia during June and early July, and Centaurea nigra, C. scabiosa, Knautia arvensis and Scabiosa columbaria from late July-September. Bumblebees, particularly Bombus lapidarius, were the most abundant visitors to most of these plant species; Apis mellifera, some Lepidoptera and Syrphidae were of lesser importance. Some insect species differed in the flowers they visited most frequently. In the early-flowering groups of plants there was some specialization from different pollinators and divergences in flowering time, suggesting that competition for pollinators or avoidance of interspecific pollen transfer has exerted selection pressure in the past. In the late-summer group all species overlapped considerably in flowering time and their insect visitors, which suggests that there has not been any strong selection against an overlap. There appeared to be a saturation of insect visitors in late summer, with particularly large numbers of B. lapidarius.-from Author

dc:title: Population dynamics of the wild daffodil ( Narcissus pseudonarcissus). III. Implications of a computer model of 1000 years of population change.
dc:creator: Barkham J.
dc:description: Consequences of varying rates of mortality, clonal growth and seed reproduction are explored for a population of daffodil over a 1000-yr period, using a simulation model. When field-based rates of reproduction and mortality were kept constant over a long period, or varied under a simulated coppice cycle, extinction of the population or attainment of unacceptably high densities generally resulted. Stabilization at realistic densities was achieved by modifying values for clonal growth to rates intermediate between the extremes recorded in the field. At normal rates of fertility and mortality there is a continuous turnover of genets. Increasing the rate of clonal growth increased the probability of genet survival and hence the number of genets. A low-density pattern of individuals and clumps could be produced by certain combinations of mortality and fertility rate; competition from other plant species or unsuitability of the environment was not required to explain gaps between individuals or clumps. Clumps might consist of the members of more than one genet, as, over a period of several hundred years, a long-lived genet might become dispersed and parts of it come to lie adjacent to other genets.-from Authors

dc:title: Effects of parent plant density on the production of achene types in the annual Hypochoeris glabra.
dc:creator: Baker G.
dc:description: Hypochoeris glabra produces 2 different achene types, beaked and unbeaked, produced simultaneously on the same receptacle but the number of each type and the proportions varying. At low parent- plant density a greater proportion of the beaked achene type is produced than at high densities due to changes in receptacle size. Plant weight and scape height are also reduced at high parent-plant density. The beaked achene, falling through air, has a lower terminal velocity and is more likely to be dispersed further by wind than the heavier unbeaked achene is. The structure of the unbeaked achene helps it to adhere to animals. Achenes produced by the shorter, high density, plants are probably dispersed to a smaller distance than are those produced on taller, low density, plants. In these conditions it would be advantageous to have a higher proportion of the animal-dispersed, unbeaked achenes.-from Authors

dc:title: The relationships between oak tree growth and climate in Britain.
dc:creator: Pilcher J.
dc:description: High rainfall, particularly in the growing season, and high temperatures in early summer favour growth of Quercus petraea and Q. robur. High temperatures in the previous winter are detrimental to growth in the following season perhaps due to loss of food reserves. -from Authors

dc:title: Some effects of post- fire age on the above-ground plant biomass of fynbos ( macchia) vegetation in South Africa.
dc:creator: Van Wilgen B.W.
dc:description: The biomass was 670 g m-2 4 yr after burning; all of this was potential fuel. Fynbos 21 yr after burning had a biomass of 5100 g m-2 of which about half was potential fuel. Fynbos protected from fire for 37 yr had a biomass of 7600 g m-2, of which more than half was potential fuel. Frequent burning keeps the biomass low. Protection from fire for longer than 30 yr results in a decline in live biomass and an accumulation of litter and potentially burnable vegetation. Fires in such senescent stands are usually very severe. -from Author

dc:title: Two radiocarbon-dated pollen diagrams from high-altitude blanket peats in South Wales.
dc:creator: Chambers F.
dc:description: Cefn Ffordd, NW of Rhondda, has a shallow, peaty gleyed soil supporting Molinia bog at 600m OD, the highest altitude in Glamorgan. Brecon Beacons has deeper, hagged hill peat at 715m on the Brecon Beacons escarpment, 1.5km east of Pen-y-Fan. At the Brecon Beacons site the peat dates from the (late) Neolithic, and at Cefn Ffordd from the (early) Bronze Age; at the higher-altitude site the peat formed earlier. Prehistoric man may have influenced the initiation of these blanket peats as there is some evidence in horizons close to the mineral-peat transition for his activity in the area. -from Author

dc:title: Vertical separation of light and available nutrients as a factor causing replacement of green algae by blue-green algae in the plankton of a stratified lake.
dc:creator: Ganf G.
dc:description: A change from the green alga, Dictyosphaerium pulchellum to the blue-green algae Microcystis aeruginosa and Anabaena spiroides occurred in the plankton of Mt Bold reservoir, South Australia, during November and December 1978. The reservoir was 30-34 m deep, thermally stratified with water mixed to 6-7 m, and a euphotic zone of less than 2.7 m. Photosynthesis was restricted probably to the upper 2.5 m. During this change there was a decline of the potential of the water for algal growth to undetectable levels at a depth of 8 m. This could be restored by the combined addition of N, P and Fe-EDTA. The blue-green algal community was able to migrate to a depth of 12 m despite substantial density barriers. Populations which were artificially circulated between 0.2 and 10 m, were able to grow, whereas those maintained at a single depth (0.2 m or 10 m) were not. The ability of blue-green algae to overcome successfully this spatial separation between light and nutrients is the probable cause of the change from green to blue-green algae.-from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal changes in weight of above- and below-ground vegetation and dead plant material in a salt marsh at Colne Point, Essex.
dc:creator: Hussey A.
dc:description: Randomly selected quadrats in a 1-ha study area of a marsh dominated by Puccinellia maritima and Halimione portulacoides were harvested by cutting above-ground material and extracting below-ground material from soil cores. Dry-weight of live material per unit area, averaged over a year, was 660 + or - 36 g m-2 with a summer maximum of 831 + or - 75 g m-2. Some 55% of this biomass was below-ground. Large amounts of dead vegetation were found throughout the year, an average of 4800 + or - 168 g m- 2 and a maximum of 5820 + or - 281 g m-2. Some 85% of this material was below-ground. Amounts of live vegetation are similar to those reported for N. American marshes at similar latitudes, but amounts of dead vegetation are much higher. Live vegetation and litter on the marsh constituted a large potential source of energy and reduced carbon for other trophic levels, both in the salt marsh and adjacent coastal ecosystems.-from Authors

dc:title: Use of a relative physiological performance value in the prediction of performance in multispecies mixtures from monoculture performance ( Holcus lanatus).
dc:creator: Austin M.
dc:description: A relative physiological performance value is defined and used to determine relative physiological performance curves for species in relation to a nutrient gradient, using data from a published experiment where performance in monoculture and in 5- and 10- species mixtures was recorded. A normalized ecological performance value was defined for multispecies mixtures. Examination of the residuals from the regressions, particularly for the 10-species mixture, indicates that specific effects associated with particular species at particular positions along the gradient are important. In particular, Holcus lanatus performance was not well predicted due to its exploitation of a niche (horizontal growth over the sides of the pots) not available to erect growing species. Species ecological maxima in multispecies mixtures correspond in position along the gradient with the species maximum values for the relative physiological performance, but do not correspond with the physiological optima measured using absolute yield.-from Author Div. of Land Use Res., Inst. of Earth Res., CSIRO, Canberra, Australia.

dc:title: Control of relative abundance in roadside Arrhenatheretum: results of a long-term garden experiment.
dc:creator: Grubb P.
dc:description: Species used were Arrhenatherum elatius (overwhelmingly the largest biomass at field sites), Dactylis glomerata (a tall grass of high frequency but a much lower mean biomass), Festuca rubra (a shorter grass of high frequency and low mean biomass) and Plantago lanceolata (a forb of moderate frequency and low mean biomass). Harvests taken after 1 and 2 yr (1974 and 1975) yielded useful information on the potential for short-term interference, but the most valuable results did not emerge until 1978, when the abilities of the various species to invade and replace each other became apparent. The overwhelming abundance of A. elatius at field sites is interpreted as being a result of its ability to invade and suppress all 3 other species, and to exclude invaders where it is established in single-species stands. D. glomerata and P. lanceolata possibly retain their place in the community by being superior to A elatius in invading gaps, at least under certain conditions. Festuca rubra grows slowly at first, but it spreads widely by stolons, persists for a long time, and forms an understorey to A. elatius. The lesser frequency as well as smaller mean biomass of P. lanceolata, compared with D. glomerata and F. rubra, is probably a result of its being shorter-lived than the other 2 under a regime of once-yearly cutting.-from Author

dc:title: Growth rate and temperature responses in bryophytes. II. A comparative study of species of contrasted ecology.
dc:creator: Furness S.
dc:description: Forty species of bryophyte of contrasted growth-form and ecology were grown under controlled laboratory conditions using a standardized procedure. Results allow the mean relative growth rate of the species to be compared over the temperature range 5-35oC. Mean relative growth rate varied considerably with temperature and according to the ecology of the species. High values were recorded in the ruderal species Funaria hygrometrica and in perennial pleurocarpous species of fertile habitats, eg. Brachythecium rutabulum. Low values typified species of continuously unproductive habitats and were particularly characteristic of lithophytes. The optimal temperature for growth in the majority of species was 15-25oC; in many species there was a considerable gain in dry weight at temperatures <10o. With respect to growth at temperatures <18oC, shoots of B. rutabulum obtained in winter were superior to those collected in summer. All species were killed, often very rapidly, when maintained in a continuously moist condition at 35oC and many species died eventually when kept continuously at temperatures >30oC.-from Authors

dc:title: Some plant growth patterns in relation to the sand dune habitat.
dc:creator: Boorman L.
dc:description: Winter annual species had high growth rates and except in the earliest stages, the shoots showed greater increase in dry weight than the roots. They may have low competitive abilities and depend on the restriction of growth of perennial competitors by low soil-water and nutrient levels. Because of their high growth rates and an early start, however, they complete their life-cycle before the stress of summer drought. Some biennial and perennial species had high growth rates and are described as competitive strategists; others had quite low growth rates but tolerated extreme conditions and are described as stress-tolerant strategists. Where water and nutrients are scarce, uniformity of strategy might be expected, but there was a wide range of responses.-from Author

dc:title: The concept of strategies: use and abuse.
dc:creator: Grime J.P.
dc:description: Places in context and responds to 2 instances where information relating to strategies in plants has been misinterpreted.-from Author

dc:title: Reproductive behaviour and its individual variability in a tropical palm, Astrocaryum mexicanum.
dc:creator: Pinero D.
dc:description: The probability of reproduction is the most plastic of the reproductive characteristics analysed, since it varied between plots, age and years. Individuals respond to an environment that is heterogeneous in time and space since reproductive events were not randomly distributed among them. This probably accounts for the unsynchronized supra-annual seeding behaviour. Reproductive output was correlated with both the spatial location and the leaf area of individual palms which suggests that light may play an important role in controlling seed output. Light gaps and seed predation appear to be the most important selective pressures acting on this species.-from Authors

dc:title: A model of growth responses by Spartina alterniflora to nitrogen limitation.
dc:creator: Morris J.T.
dc:description: A model is formulated that calculates the net rate of production by a known canopy biomass as a function of incident flux of solar radiation, sun angle, air temperature, and concentration of N in green leaves. This model accounted for 82% of the variability in specific leaf dry-weight growth rate, SGR (% day-1), in all treatments for the duration of the experiment from 9 June to 18 November. Leaf-N concentration decreased to 1% of dry weight during mid-summer in plants limited by N, but remained above 2% at all times in plants not limited by N. Concentration of N in leaves had little effect on SGR, but 49% of variability in SGR was explained by a linear regression on solar radiation, ie. the temporal changes in SGR were largely dependent on climatic factors. Differences in total plant production were attributed to differences in the ratio of growth rate of photosynthetic:nonphotosynthetic tissue rather than to changes in SGR. The growth rate of aerial biomass was initially 1.7-2.8 times that of below-ground biomass, depending on the treatment, while eventually this quotient decreased to less than 1.0. Although aerial and rhizome production were stimulated by increased N supply, total root production did not differ significantly between treatments. -from Author

dc:title: Growth, phosphate absorption, and phosphorous chemical fractions in two Chionochloa species.
dc:creator: Chapin F.S.
dc:description: Seedlings of two New Zealand alpine grasses were grown in solution culture with three rates of phosphate supply. Chionochloa pallens typically grows in soils in which more phosphate is available than is in soils occupied by C. crassiuscula. A low P requirement associated with slow growth is more important than between-species differences in P metabolism, phosphate absorption, or efficiency of P utilization in explaining the success of C. crassiuscula and other low-P-adapted species on infertile soils. -from Authors

dc:title: Adenylate energy charge measurements in freshwater microbial studies.
dc:creator: Jewson D.
dc:description: Measurements were made of ATP, ADP and AMP concentrations and the corresponding adenylate energy charge quotient (EC), to assess their potential as indicators of the metabolic state of freshwater micro-organisms. Decreases in EC from 0.81-0.68 during filtration, and from 0.90-0.69, during light/dark shocks, may result in errors of over 60% in the estimated ATP content of cells, if care is not taken during extraction. The EC values, during logarithmic growth in culture, of the blue-green algae Oscillatoria agardhii and O. redekei were 0.82 and 0.83 respectively. These declined to 0.57 and 0.63 after N limitation in culture. In a well-mixed lake (Lough Neagh, Northern Ireland) where both these species occur, no change in the EC quotient (0.9 + or - 0.04) was detected in the water column between April-November. Greater variation was found in a range of deep, stratified lakes in Austria (Wallersee, Mondsee, Attersee); factors influencing the depth differences in EC quotients, ranging from 0.47-0.82, are discussed.-Authors blue green algae Oscillatoria agardhii/redekei Lough Neagh Northern Ireland

dc:title: Stratigraphy of a site in the Munsary Dubh Lochs, Caithness, northern Scotland: development of the present pattern ( blanket mire).
dc:creator: Smart P.
dc:description: The Munsary Dubh Lochs are a good example of a blanket mire whose surface displays a pattern of hummocks, ridges and pools. A description of the vegetation is given, emphasizing contemporary microtopographical features of the mire surface. The sequence of deposits suggests that a pool phase, initiated relatively early in the development of the mire, was followed by a period during which it is likely that no pools were present. Later, the present day pool formed in a slightly different position from that of the early pool.-from Author

dc:title: The ecology of a montane grassland in Sri Lanka. II. The pattern of four major species.
dc:creator: Amarasinghe L.
dc:description: Several scales of pattern were present. The 20-40-cm scale of pattern of Cymbopogon nardus, Pennisetum polystachyon and Themeda tremula was attributed to their tussock-size, and that of Eulalia trispicata to dispersal of its seeds as aggregates. The 80-cm scale of pattern of C. nardus and E. trispicata was related to variation in soil compactness. In the 2 less-disturbed communities, C. nardus occurred more in hollows than on hummocks, while the reverse was true for E. trispicata and T. tremula, so causing their pattern at the 160-320-cm scale. However, in the 2 more-disturbed communities, the aggressive weed Pennisetum polystachyon occurred more in hollows, from which it excluded C. nardus.-from Authors

dc:title: Inorganic nutrition of Rubus vestitus in a mixed deciduous woodland.
dc:creator: Taylor K.
dc:description: Maximum amounts of N, P, K, Ca and Mg per plant in the aerial parts of R. vestitus in Meathop Wood, Cumbria, were reached by mid-July and were at least double the winter minima. A large proportion of these accumulated nutrients was taken up from the soil. Maximum values for N, P and K occurred early in the year in the newly developing leaves, followed by a rapid decline as the growing season progressed. Values for Mg remained constant, Ca concentration increased steadily during the same period. The least well grown plants on shallow brown-earth soils tended also to have the lowest concentration of P and K. -from Author

dc:title: A numerical analysis of tropical rain forest using floristic and structural data and its application to an analysis of gibbon ranging behaviour.
dc:creator: Whitten A.
dc:description: In Lowland Evergreen Rain forest on Siberut Island, Indonesia, nine forest types were derived, and interpreted ecologically: one on dry level ground, one on wet level ground, one on peatswamp, two on major ridges, and four on minor ridges. These types were generally recognizable by indicator species, and that gibbons recognized them too was reflected in their behaviour. The number of times that Kloss gibbons (Hylobates klossii) were seen feeding in a forest type was very highly correlated with the density of trees that were potential fruit sources for gibbons. Female gibbons sang from those forest types with the trees that were tallest and above the break of slope. The gibbon group slept in those forest types in which the trees had a low frequency of the myrmecophilous epiphyte Myrmecodia tuberosa, presumably to avoid being bitten by ants. Forest types such as peatswamp were under-used consistently, while others such as those on minor ridges were used disproportionately often for certain activities. A 4-dimensional view of gibbon home range was possible by including differential canopy use and changes in behaviour through the day. -from Author

dc:title: Experimental ecological genetics in Plantago. IV. The demography of seedling transplants of P. lanceolata.
dc:creator: Antonovics J.
dc:description: The relative importance of genotype and of environment in determining differences in life-history characters such as mortality, growth rate and fecundity among populations of P. lanceolata was assessed by reciprocal transplanting of seedlings among 6 field-sites. In most cases environmental differences were much more important than genotypic ones. Different environments imposed different life-histories.-from Authors

dc:title: The ecology of a montane grassland in Sri Lanka. IV. Vegetative growth of four major grasses.
dc:creator: Amarasinghe L.
dc:description: Cymbopogon nardus, Eulalia trispicata, Pennisetum polystachyon and Themeda tremula were studied in pot experiments using natural soils. All species withstood considerable soil moisture stress, but required high soil moisture for satisfactory growth. Addition of a complete nutrient solution increased growth rate considerably. There was much less growth in pots lacking added N, P or K, and in those given water only; the combined effect of these 3 elements was greater than their individual effects. High density caused substantial reduction of vegetative size, fertility, and reproductive capacity of E. trispicata, P. polystachyon and T. tremula; density effects on C. nardus were not investigated. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonality and phenology in a dry tropical forest in Ghana
dc:creator: Lieberman D.
dc:description: Flowering, fruiting, leaf production, leaf fall and girth changes all show a strong seasonal pattern in a tropical forest and grassland/thicket mosaic in Ghana. Moisture deficits limit phenological activity although patterns vary among species. Dry-fruit species fruit principally in dry seasons. Fleshy-fruited species fruit in either wet or dry seasons, although freshy fruits are most abundant in wet seasons. Species grouped according to habitat and life-form show similar patterns of flowering and fruiting. Leaf flushing is limited to wet seasons, although not all species or individuals produce new leaves each wet season. Leaf fall occurs in dry seasons; 19% of forest species and 55% of grassland/thicket species became fully leafless during the study period. Girth changes are closely related to rainfall and foliage phenology. The amplitude of girth changes is related to the habitat of the species, with greater seasonal changes occurring under more exposed conditions. Net girth increments over the 15-month period were negative, due to unusually low rainfall.-from Author

dc:title: Growth rate and temperature responses in bryophytes. I. An investigation of Brachythecium rutabulum.
dc:creator: Furness S.
dc:description: Over a period of 30 days, this perennial pleurocarpous moss maintained exponential growth and attained a relative growth rate of 0.071 day-1. In a temperature gradient, maxima in relative growth rate, shoot length and leaf area occurred at c.19oC but at 5oC the reduction in relative growth rate was <40%. The comparatively high relative growth rate of B. rutabulum is consistent with the large amplitude of seasonal change in biomass and rapid turnover of shoots observed under natural conditions. The capacity to grow at low temperature may be related to the tendency of the species to exploit the cool conditions of spring and autumn and may also explain the ability of the species to co-exist with productive vascular plants. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of seed size on the germination, growth and competitive ability of Rumex crispus and Rumex obtusifolius.
dc:creator: Cideciyan M.
dc:description: Seed size has no effect on percentage germination of R. obtusifolius or on the heavier seeds of R. crispus but germination of small seeds of R. crispus is reduced. Germination rate of seeds of R. obtusifolius increases as seed size decreases. Seed size has no effect on subsequent growth of R. crispus. In R. obtusifolius initial growth is slower from smaller seeds, though no difference is detectable at the end of the growing season. Intraspecific competition results in reduced growth of plants from 1.4 to 1.2 mm seeds compared with those from >1.4 mm seeds, but there are no competitive interactions. Results are interpreted in terms of the response of the Rumex species to grazing by the chrysomelid beetle, Gastrophysa viridula.-Authors

dc:title: Limitation of the recruitment of the shrub Haplopappus squarrosus ( Asteraceae) by flower- and seed-feeding insects.
dc:creator: Louda S.
dc:description: Application of insecticide during flower development and fruit maturation reduced the loss of fruits caused by tephritid flies, microlepidopteran moths and chalcidoid wasps from 94% to 41%. This reduction in insect damage to flowers, developing ovules and seeds had three major effects: number of viable seeds increased significantly; density of seedlings increased significantly, and number of young plants which were recruited after 1 yr increased significantly. Flower- and seed-feeding insects thus appear to be the proximate factor limiting recruitment and abundance of H. squarrosus in the coastal environment of California. -from Author

dc:title: Patch dynamics of plant succession on abandoned surface coal mines: a case history approach ( Missouri).
dc:creator: Game M.
dc:description: Despite differences in the rates of natural revegetation, the 6 sites in Missouri were rapidly colonized by plants which grew to form patches. These patches grew at a uniform rate, while new patches were also formed. Eventually, the patches coalesced and dominated the surface. Grazing of one site reduced total cover and produced a transient fission of patches so that, for a short time, their density increased and non-circularity decreased.-from Authors
